items.question: What does baking soda do?
items.answer: It’s a leavening agent and acidity regulator: when it reacts with an acid and heat, it releases CO2 that makes batters and doughs rise. It also raises pH, promoting browning and a crisper texture.

items.question: What's the difference between baking soda and baking powder?
items.answer: Baking soda is pure sodium bicarbonate and needs an acidic ingredient to work. Baking powder contains sodium bicarbonate plus acids and starch, often double-acting to release gas when moistened and again when heated.
items.source: what's the difference between baking soda and baking powder

items.question: Can i use baking soda instead of baking powder?
items.answer: Yes—add an acid: for each 1 tsp baking powder, use about 1/4 tsp baking soda plus 1/2 tsp cream of tartar (or another acid), adjusting liquids if using buttermilk/yogurt/lemon juice. Without added acid, it won’t rise properly and can taste soapy.
items.source: can i use baking soda instead of baking powder

items.question: Does baking soda go bad?
items.answer: It doesn’t spoil, but it loses leavening strength after opening—best within about 6 months. Test by adding some to vinegar or lemon juice; vigorous fizz means it’s still active.

items.question: Can i use baking powder instead of baking soda?
items.answer: Often, yes—use roughly 3 times as much baking powder as baking soda and, if possible, reduce other acidic ingredients to avoid tartness. Expect a slight change in flavor/texture due to added starch and acids.
items.source: can i use baking powder instead of baking soda
